text: I worked on a project at a company
called lmax where we built one of the
world's highest performance Financial
exchanges and at some point one day the
team that I was working with at the time
we we finished we just finished an
estimation session and it was lunchtime
on a Friday or something like that so
being England we went to the pub for
lunch and we were sat in the pub
actually no it was after work we we were
socializing so after work and our
product owner came in and she said oh hi
how's everybody and she came and sat
down with us and we were chatting it and
she said what you guys been doing we
said oh we just we just finished an
estimation instead session he said how
do you still do that and we kind of
looked at her and said
what do you mean do we still do that
we're doing it for you he said I haven't
been looking at those for months so what
do you mean you're gonna be looking at
this he said look I did a statistical
breakdown and if we just count the
number of stories that we've got and
project that forward that's more
accurate than your estimates as a
predictive tool so I just rely on that
yeah wow and so and and so we stopped
doing estimation at that point I said
I'd come back to the idea of the
predictability I think that one of the
things that working in an agile way
there's many small steps gives you is
the ability to optimize for either
predictability
or efficiency but if you want to be
predictable the way that you're
predictable is that you're building up
enough error margin that you're not very
efficient so Agile development is
wonderful at hitting a date if you ask
most organizations what do you want
do you want to be able to hit
